problem:
Simplify
\[4 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) \sin (60^\circ + x).\]The answer will be a trigonometric function of some simple function of $x,$ like "$\cos (2x)$" or "$\sin (x^3)$".
model_solution:
Step 1: Use the product-to-sum identity
\[\sin a \sin b = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (a - b) - \cos (a + b) \right].\]
Set $a = 60^\circ - x$ and $b = x.$
Step 2: 
\begin{align*}
4 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) \sin (60^\circ + x) &= 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ + x) \\
&= 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \right] 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \right] \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \frac{1}{2} \right) \left( -\frac{1}{2} - \cos 2x \right).
\end{align*}
\begin{align*}
\left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \frac{1}{2} \right) \left( -\frac{1}{2} - \cos 2x \right) &= \frac{1}{4} - \frac{\cos (60^\circ - 2x)}{2} - \frac{\cos 2x}{2} - \frac{1}{4} \cos 2x + \frac{1}{4} \cos (60^\circ - 2x) \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (60^\circ - 2x) + \cos 2x \right] - \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos 2x + \cos (60^\circ - 2x) \right] \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (60^\circ - 2x) + \cos 2x \right] - \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (2x - 60^\circ) + \cos (2x + 60^\circ)
Using the sum-to-product identity
\[\cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos \left(\frac{a + b}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{a - b}{2}\right)\]
set $a = 60^\circ - 2x$ and $b = 2x.$
\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (60^\circ - 2x) + \cos 2x \right] - \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (2x - 60^\circ) + \cos (2x + 60^\circ) \right] &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ 2 \cos \left(\frac{60^\circ - 2x + 2x}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{60^\circ - 2x - 2x}{2}\right) \right] \\
&\quad - \frac{1}{2} \left[ 2 \cos \left(\frac{2x - 60^\circ + 2x}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{2x - 60^\circ - 2x}{2}\right) \right] \\
&= \cos 30^\circ \cos (-x) - \cos x \cos 90^\circ \\
&= \cos 30^\circ \cos x - 0 \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{3}}
\begin{align*}
\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos x &= \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4} (2 \cos x)} \\
Final Answer: The final answer is \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos x.
steps:
Step 1: Use the product-to-sum identity
\[\sin a \sin b = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (a - b) - \cos (a + b) \right].\]
Set $a = 60^\circ - x$ and $b = x.$

Step 2: 
\begin{align*}
4 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) \sin (60^\circ + x) &= 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ + x) \\
&= 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \right] 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \right] \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \frac{1}{2} \right) \left( -\frac{1}{2} - \cos 2x \right).
\end{align*}

Using the sum-to-product identity
\[\cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos \left(\frac{a + b}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{a - b}{2}\right)\]
set $a = 60^\circ - 2x$ and $b = 2x.$
Final Answer: The final answer is \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos x.
full_steps:
Step 1: Use the product-to-sum identity
\[\sin a \sin b = \frac{1}{2} \left[ \cos (a - b) - \cos (a + b) \right].\]
Set $a = 60^\circ - x$ and $b = x.$

Step 2: 
\begin{align*}
4 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) \sin (60^\circ + x) &= 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ - x) 2 \sin x \sin (60^\circ + x) \\
&= 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \right] 2 \left[ \frac{1}{2} \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \right] \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \cos (60^\circ) \right) \left( \cos (120^\circ) - \cos 2x \right) \\
&= \left( \cos (60^\circ - 2x) - \frac{1}{2} \right) \left( -\frac{1}{2} - \cos 2x \right).
\end{align*}

Using the sum-to-product identity
\[\cos a + \cos b = 2 \cos \left(\frac{a + b}{2}\right) \cos \left(\frac{a - b}{2}\right)\]
set $a = 60^\circ - 2x$ and $b = 2x.$
Final Answer: The final answer is \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \cos x.
